p: Tail flicking in rodents is a response of pain caused by the heat stimulus to measure the efficacy of antinociceptive activity. The results of the tail flick test are shown in Table 4; the tail flick time of control mice was 3.75 ± 0.38 s. The mice treated with trazodone hydrochloride exhibited a slight decrease in the tail flick time (3.49 ± 0.32 s) without statistical significance ( p < 0.05). No differences were found between the mice treated with different doses (100–400 mg/Kg) of leaf oil; the tail flick time was between 3.81–4.01 s. The results indicated that both the leaf oil and trazodone hydrochloride did not exhibit the antinociceptive activity for the experimental mice.
